indicators.justification:
According to the Ministry of Environment, Morocco has 29 stations to measure air quality in the country (1). The research did not find any of this data published online.

Source:
(1) https://www.environnement.gov.ma/images/AIR/Ar/Air_Ar-2-min.pdf

indicators.justification:
Only literature found on ministry of environment (1), ministry of Agriculture - water and forest department (2). There is also a center created in 2004 by Morocco to exchange information on biodiversity, however this website was not working during the research and after checking the Internet archive there are no information published on this website either (3). However there is another website which include a database on biodiversity including 5053 species, 802 families, 242 orders et 46 classes, however this website is also not working too (4).

## References

1- https://www.environnement.gov.ma/fr/biodiversite
2- http://www.eauxetforets.gov.ma/Biodiversite/Biodiversit%C3%A9%20au%20Maroc/Pages/Biodiversit%C3%A9-au-Maroc.aspx
3- https://ma.chm-cbd.net/
4- http://www.biodiversite-maroc.com/biodive/accueil.do

indicators.justification:
Some information are published as part of the daily report by the health ministry such as COVID-19 intensive care bed occupancy rate, last 24 critical cases, Total artificial respiration case, Cases under non-invasive ventilation. (1)

A dashboard is also available including healthcare infrastructure during 2020 (2). However there is no real-time capacity of the healthcare system available in Morocco.

1- http://www.covidmaroc.ma/Documents/BULLETIN/24.7.21.COVID-19.pdf

indicators.justification:
There is no public consultation information available in Morocco. Only a few public consultations are found on separate websites (1)(2). Data found in IMANOR are mainly related to Standardization Commission and include a word document per consultation with Reference, commission name, Responsible name, and key dates from opening to the closing.

The second link is related to The Millennium Challenge Account-Morocco Agency,  a public institution created in September 2016, in charge of implementing a joint-program between the Government of the Kingdom of Morocco and the Government of the United States of America (3).

Sources:
(1) https://www.imanor.gov.ma/enquetes-publiques/
(2) https://www.mcamorocco.ma/sites/default/files/documents/Plan%20et%20mise%20en%20%C5%93uvre%20de%20la%20consultation%20publique_0.pdf
(3) https://www.mcamorocco.ma/en

(1) http://www.data.gov.ma/fr/la-licence
(2) https://opendatacommons.org/licenses/odbl/1-0/

responses.response_text: There is isolated evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.
There is evidence of government efforts to support private sector or NGO data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

indicators.justification:
According to the Morocco first OGP plan, there is a commitment number 4 (1) related to increasing the publication and reuse of open data. This commitment focuses on:
- Creating a national data strategy
- Creating governance for open data to coordinate the policy of openness and the sharing and reuse of public data to include all stakeholders, including the private sector and civil society.
-Implanting an organisation within the ministerial departments, public institutions, and territorial authorities that enables the selection, collection, categorisation, and validation of data to be provided to the public or published according to the laws in force.
-Developing manual setting rules for collecting, processing, disseminating, and updating open data.
-Training data officers within government departments and public institutions on rules for collecting, processing, disseminating, and updating open data.
-Communicating and raising public's awareness (government departments, citizens, companies, researchers, tourists, investors, civil society, etc.) about the benefits of openness, sharing, and reuse of data. 

According to an official responsible for the commitment 4, things were on hold regarding this commitment (2). 

###Refrences

indicators.justification:
The Moroccan Digital Development Agency mentioned that they are working on a large project titled "Digital Generation" project. The project consists of setting up a national digital training program to include new digital professions in higher education, continuing education, vocational training and scientific research as well as promoting digital culture among young people and citizens. There is no indication if the project will include training on data matter specifically, however this should be available as part of objective of improving the employability of Moroccans by training them for the jobs of tomorrow. (1)

indicators.justification:
The political party law in Morocco does not require interoperability across different political integrity datasets, as well as other datasets associated with relevant information flows (1). 

Source:
(1)https://www.maroc.ma/fr/system/files/documents_page/loi_partis_fr.pdf

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
Doing business in Morocco is subject to the "Code de Commerce" or Commerce Law updated in 2014 (1). The law requires maintaining a central businesses register. However, there is no obligation to publish it.

The research did not find any regulations, policies, and guidance that provide a basis for collecting and publishing beneficial ownership data on companies. However there is an online database from OMPIC (2) (Moroccan Office of Industrial and Commercial property) which allows access to various OMPICs databases as well as international databases. The information available here includes; designs and industrial models; patents; commercial names which is a list of companies enrolled in the Trade Registry and a list of corporate names. However, during the research, the online database was not working making it impossible to check the kind of information available. 

There is instead another portal which is working instead (3). The portal provides general information : Company name, registration number and date, and activity. 

Sources:
(1)http://62.251.167.25/sites/default/files/code%20de%20commerce%202014%20-%20fr.pdf
(2)http://www.ompic.org.ma/en/content/research-ompic-databases
(3) http://www.directompic.ma/fr/cpm

indicators.justification:
Morocco has a comprehensive data protection framework, text Law No 09-08, dated February 18, 2009. It is available at the official website of the Data Protection National Commission (Commission Nationale de Protection des Données Personnelles). (1)

Sources:
(1)https://www.cndp.ma/fr/espace-juridique/textes-et-lois.html

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.
The framework provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves.
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework applies widely in one or more sectors.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.

indicators.justification:
In their first national OGP plan, Morocco made a commitment number 4 related to increasing publication and reuse of open data (1). The commitment consists of 
- Creating a national data strategy, 
- Creating governance for open data to coordinate the policy of openness and the sharing and reuse of public data to include all stakeholders, including the private sector and civil society, 
- Implanting an organization within the ministerial departments, public institutions, and territorial authorities that enables the selection, collection, categorization, and validation of data to be
provided to the public or published according to the laws in force
- Developing manual setting rules for collecting, processing, disseminating, and updating open data.
- Training data officers within government departments and public institutions on rules for collecting, processing, disseminating, and updating open data.
- Communicating and raising public awareness (government departments, citizens, companies, researchers, tourists, investors, civil society, etc.) about the benefits of openness, sharing, and reuse of data. 

IRM report indicates that an open data action plan was being drafted (2), however, there is nothing published.


Source:
(1) https://www.opengovpartnership.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Morocco_Action-Plan_2018-2020_EN_Revised.pdf
(2) https://www.opengovpartnership.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Morocco_Design_Report_2018-2020_EN_for-public-comment.pdf

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

indicators.justification:
Public finance in Morocco is governed by the Finance Law, which is defined and subject to the organic law 130-13 (1). The law defines the legal and technical procedures required to implement Finance Laws in Morocco. Article 66, mentions the required documents that should be provided for the Government Budget, and spending. The Finance law execution report should be provided to the court of auditors, parliament, and to the Government.

Source: 
(1) http://lof.finances.gov.ma/sites/default/files/loi_organique_130-30_fr18.pdf

indicators.justification:
The political parties law 29-11 of 2011 (1) mentions in article 44 that "all political parties, must produce their annual accounts to the Court of Auditors by March 31 of each year at the latest, certified by an accountant registered on the roll of the order of accountants, and must justify that the amounts received by them have been used, for the purpose for which they were granted".

(1)https://www.maroc.ma/fr/system/files/documents_page/loi_partis_fr.pdf
